text:
$NOW acquires Armis for ~$7B (its largest deal ever) adding device-level cyber security across IoT, medical & industrial endpoints.

Armis has scaled ARR from $200M to $300M in under year which gives ServiceNow a native cyber visibility layer that fits directly into its enterprise workflow platform.

THE 3 FIXES $HIMS NEEDS RIGHT NOW

1. Fix the top of the funnel so new customers start growing again  

Hims built its whole business on being able to bring in huge numbers of new customers cheaply and easily. That stopped working when marketing got more expensive and net new subscribers slowed. Even though Hims has more than 2.5M subscribers today, the engine isn't adding people fast enough unless the company leans harder on raising ARPU.

I also donâ€™t buy the idea that this is ONLY a Sexual Health issue shifting from episodic to subscription SKUs. The broader truth is that digital ads are more expensive, more crowded and harder to win now that companies like $AMZN & $GOOGL are competing for the same customers.

The fastest way to reset sentiment is to stabilize CAC, and Hims can do that by publishing more transparent funnel metrics and shifting ~25% of marketing spend into high-intent, low-CAC channels that actually scale. Even one or two quarters where CAC flattens would flip the narrative because it proves the engine can still scale efficiently.

2. Make Diagnostics the default onboarding path

Diagnostics can change the business because it gives Hims a way to guide every new user into the correct treatment path instead of hoping they arrive through a single-category entry point like hair loss or sexual health. If diagnostics becomes the front door then someone might come in for one issue but stay for multiple conditions over time.

That increases retention, raises lifetime value and stabilizes revenue. For this to work Hims needs to route all new users into a single diagnostic intake, build a recommendation engine that automatically matches users to the right care categories and follow up with personalized plans that raise ARPU naturally instead of relying on blunt upsells.

3. How Palantirâ€™s ontology would help Hims fix acquisition

Hims has one of the richest data sets in consumer healthcare. They already know how different conditions convert, how long users stay on treatments, what causes churn, when people switch categories and what long-term health journeys look like. The problem is that this data lives in separate systems and teams, which means they see pieces of the puzzle but not the whole picture.

This is exactly the kind of problem $PLTR ontology is built to solve and if I were @AndrewDudum this would be one of my highest-priority initiatives. 

Palantirâ€™s ontology acts like an organizational brain that connects data from every corner of the company and shows how everything fits together in real time. It would let Hims see the entire customer journey as one unified system from the moment someone clicks a TikTok ad, to their first prescription, to refill behavior, to switching into new categories and long-term retention.

Right now Hims sees each part of the customer journey in isolation but Palantir would let them stitch it into one living system that updates in real time and actually explains why cohorts behave the way they do.

This chart is exactly why I think the AI bubble is still years away.

When peak power needed breaks away from peak power available around 2028 it makes clear that the real limit on AI is no longer how many GPUs $NVDA can ship but how much energy the grid can actually deliver to run them.

Once that gap opens the entire ecosystem gets pushed into a digestion phase. Not because AI adoption slows but because the grid becomes the binding constraint which is when the S-curve behavior shows up.

AI bears will point to that period and call it the bursting of the AI bubble but itâ€™s really just the moment where the physical economy has to catch up to the digital one.

Robotics will be a major 2026 theme as it becomes the physical expression of the AI economy.

The companies that own data, distribution, simulation & real-world deployment will define the next decade of productivity.

Jensen Huang says self-driving will be the first multi-trillion-dollar robotics market.

The companies best positioned:
â€¢ $NVDA fueling robotic intelligence
â€¢ $AMZN automating logistics at scale
â€¢ $ISRG transforming surgery with robotics
â€¢ $TSLA leading with real-world humanoid AI
â€¢ $PLTR orchestrating real-time intelligence for autonomous systems

MY 2026 PREDICTIONS

1. Amazon goes from Mag-7 laggard to leader as AWS reaccelerates.
Compute bottlenecks fade, Trainium gains real adoption & AWS growth moves back toward the mid-twenties, while Ads continues its steady climb & becomes a second profit engine that structurally lifts $AMZN margins.

2. Space industry becomes a mainstream investment theme.
A $1.5T SpaceX IPO forces public markets to rethink what the space economy is actually worth. That shift accelerates as Sam Altman explores a direct SpaceX competitor & as Sundar Pichai, Jeff Bezos & Elon Musk openly discuss orbital compute which creates a rare moment where politics, capital & technology align. $RKLB & $ASTS are my highest-conviction ways to express that re-rating.

3. Emerging markets outperform the S&P 500.
A weaker dollar, lower rates and an explosion of digital products built from AI tools give EM a structural tailwind, with Latin America positioned to benefit the most. $MELI remains my highest-conviction expression of this theme.

4. Model costs collapse again & push value to whoever controls distribution.
As inference becomes cheaper & model performance converges then the models themselves stop being the profit center & the power shifts to platforms that own consumer engagement. $META, $GOOGL & $AAPL outperform because distribution becomes the moat since they control the surfaces where billions interact with AI every day.

5. Productivity boom finally shows up in the data.
The Fedâ€™s GDP upgrades for 2026â€“2027 become visible as AI replaces manual workflows, raises output per worker & compresses cost structures across the economy. The gap between companies that embraced AI early & those that delayed adoption widens meaningfully in earnings.

I love trading breakouts as well. But u need a ton of other ways to create cash flow. 
Sometimes, breakouts are hard to find. 

Buy vs. levels so u can hold and add on a breakout. 

I love RDR bottom trades.  And tops for cash flow. 

Buy vs Earnings gap pivots for swings.  

Red to green vs a level on a morning gap down after a relative strength signal. 

There are many. 
I have a ton more. 

Which is ur favorite?
Keep evolving your process!
